narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Paper writing, critical reading and discussion about reading

I definitely learned how to become a better critical thinker and much better writer. The texts you read are all super interesting and making connections across all the texts is definitely really rewarding. Katja's paper feedback and meeting with her during office hours really helps make you a better writer too.
How to write  essays & analyze literature
Learned about close textual analysis & ancient literary works that serve as foundational elements of the Western Canon.
I honed my close reading skills and Professor Lindskog helped me strengthen my ability to craft an in-depth critical essay.

Developed...
-Writing skills, through crafting papers, composing discussion posts, and receiving paper feedback directly from professor
-Reading skills, by reading a lot of classical literature
-Communication skills, by listening to peers and getting in the habit of sharing thoughts articulately and clearly in seminar
-Critical thinking skills, by drawing connections within and between works

Also gained a greater appreciation for poetry while taking this course

I learned how to analyze literature in a deeper, more thoughtful way. I also learned how to craft essays that actually involve a level of detail in an exploration of certain themes in a text that I was never able to achieve before. I learned the general trajectory of western literary thought from antiquity to the medieval period in a really engaging way.
How to analyze literature and draw connections to larger themes.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was entirely strong. My only complaints are with the virtual seminar format, but I'm sure I would have very few complaints had it been in person.

Strengths were definitely Katja facilitating discussions and all the resources she provides beforehand really have with understanding sometimes very complex and nuanced texts. She is super organized and structured. I think more feedback, like generally for the whole class would be helpful. We only did one writing workshop and I feel like we could have spent a bit more time focusing on how to better write papers than analyzing the texts. Maybe one more writing workshop would have been nice.
The course moves too fast in general, and especially because we are online, a lot of the readings were not done by the students.

strengths: Katja is a wonderful, attentive, and helpful professor, who is genuinely invested in the success of her students. Course has obviously been run before and is very smooth. 

weaknesses: reading & writing can be difficult to manage at the same time
The strengths were the seminar format, the DS community, the material and incredible teaching. Professor Lindskog was always available to help us improve.

Strengths:
-curriculum is well-designed, material often overlapped with the other DS sections
-class discussions were obviously deliberate and well-planned
-Katja is great and did an excellent job making everyone feel welcome and included
-Her office hours were an extremely helpful resource, I wish I had availed myself of them even more
-Learned a great deal about classical literature as well as literature in general taking this course

Weaknesses:
-mostly due to limitations of Zoom (our section got on fine, but we fell slightly short of building the sense of community and warmth I experienced in another DS class; Katja was probably not at 100% considering it was 2am for her when our section met)
-sometimes felt frustrated when we read entire works, only to discuss 2 passages in seminar (though this is a largely a function of the DS syllabus and the necessity of moving at a fast pace)

Encouraging students to meet with one an another in person in a safe, socially distanced environment to discuss texts outside of class would have developed some really rich friendships that I feel like I missed out on, but this is only because it was such a non-traditional year for DS.
I don't see any room for improvement.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Directed studies in general has been very good about keeping student engagement high this semester. I think the seminar format worked fairly well online.

I think educationally, because this class was so small (~13 people), the seminar format translated to zoom really well, but I also felt we didn't get to bond with and learn from our classmates as much. Though our reading responses due each week gave some semblance of hearing our classmates ideas, we didn't really get to connect with each other that well. It was more like we attended class during a set time frame and that was that. There wasn't really a sense of community, but everything else like literature related was really good over zoom! Katja was really accommodating and caring about how we were literally going to school during a pandemic.
Prof. Lindskog begins each class with a 15 minute check in, which is always warming, but sometimes I wish there was more time for class discussion.
seminar was good virtually - could have maybe had more breakout rooms to make the class closer, but well run overall
I think the small seminars were very helpful for engagement. I would have gained more from the lectures if they had been available to watch synchronously, rather than asynchronously.

Whether they were covid-specific practices or not, I thought the "daily check-ins" and weekly discussion forums on Canvas were quite effective methods of building a sense of camaraderie despite the circumstances
The virtual component was still very engaging, but as mentioned above, an in-person component could have been encouraged a bit more.
The small seminar format ensured that the class was engaging and effective.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would only recommend this course to students who are very interested in reading and writing about old texts.

This course is harrrddd. It's A LOT A LOT of reading, like an insane amount so you have to be ready for that, and it really makes you think. The surface level understanding of the texts will not cut it. You really have dig down deep and have find connections, insights, backgrounds, motives, etc. and Katja will call you out on superficial stuff you say just for the sake of speaking. BUT if you were to take DS Lit, take Katja. She's amazing and really supports you as you learn to develop these critical thinking skills.
Yes, Directed Studies is an interesting lifestyle. Sure, you end up in Hell at the end of the course, but if you read a little further you get to Paradiso
Absolutely - if youre looking for an engaged professor, strong class discussion, and analyzing ancient texts

Yes! I have a much better grasp of ancient literature from thinking critically with and about ancient writers with my peers and professor. This experience not only gave me insight into the cultures and behavioral norms of the past, but also allowed me to contemplate similarities with our present.

Absolutely! To combine idioms, my two cents should be taken with a grain of salt (since I was a virtual student), but I would absolutely recommend DS literature as well as Katja's literature section (bear this in mind, anyone in DS with "scheduling conflicts"). Katja is a great person who is deeply committed to the mission of DS and who genuinely cares about the wellbeing of her students.

I would recommend this to any student interested in literature, philosophy or history, as the latter two subjects are explored through the lens of the former in the works we read. I wouldnt recommend it to someone who is not up for an insane amount of reading, but every work you read is worthwhile in this class.
Absolutely. I found myself enjoying both the literature and the discussion greatly.
